Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend who has just started assembling furniture asks for a quick video call because the instructions are confusing.
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: An online candidate forum for their district is streaming now.
Story:
I was just settling in for the evening when my phone buzzed. It was Sam, my friend who’d just moved into a new apartment. “Hey, can you hop on a quick video call? I’m drowning in these furniture instructions and could really use your help.” I glanced at the clock—7:00 p.m. The same time the online candidate forum for our district was starting, something I’d promised myself I’d watch live so I could ask questions and stay informed before voting.

As a friend, I knew Sam was counting on me. He’d helped me move last year, and I remembered how overwhelming it felt to be surrounded by boxes and cryptic diagrams. But as a citizen, I felt a responsibility to participate in the forum, to listen to the candidates and maybe even submit a question about the new park proposal. I could feel the tension building inside me, torn between being there for someone who needed me and fulfilling my civic duty. My phone buzzed again, Sam’s name lighting up the screen, while the forum’s live stream loaded on my laptop. I hesitated, caught between two worlds, unsure which expectation I should meet first.
